bug.short_desc: "Search references" and "Type hierarchy" show inconsistent results with "External Plug-in Libraries" project

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier: Version: 3.7.1 Build id: M20110909-1335
When having the same bundles in the Target Platform and as PDE projects in the workspace the "Search references in workspace" and the type hierarchy shows inconsistent results. Example: when opening the type hierarchy for an interface that is located inside a Plug-in project but the bundle containing the implementing class is part of the target platform (added to Java Search), the implementing class is NOT shown in the type hierarchy. On the other hand, if all plug-ins (or none) of the target platform are available as Plug-in projects in the workspace, the implementing class IS found.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: Using the attached example projects:
1. Start an empty eclipse workspace (3.7.1 M20110909-1335, Win32) 2. Import the example projects into your workspace 3. Set the target platform definition ("target-platform/example.target").
4. Open type hierarchy of interface "GuiComponent". You should see one class implementing this interface (from the rw.ui bundle). Everything fine so far.
5. Close all but the "gui" and "target-platform" project 6. Open the "Plug-ins" view and add the three bundles from the target platform (core, rw.biz, rw.ui) to the Java Search 7. Open again the type hierarchy of interface "GuiComponent". No implementation class is visble anymore!
8. Close the gui project too and add the gui bundle to the Java Search. 9. Open the type hierarchy of "GuiComponent": again the only implementing class is shown.

Reproduced in I20120724-0800.
Moving to JDT for comment.
PDE adds projects to the java search scope by creating a hidden project called External Plug-in Libraries. In this instance, the plug-ins containing RWGuiComponent are added correctly and they are in the java search scope (Ctrl-Shift-T open type will find it). I'm guessing that the Type Hierarchy filters out the result, possibly because it is an external plug-in with no source.
I don't think it's related to the missing source bundles. I've tried it with source bundles in the Target Platform and it also doesn't work.

Reproduced in master.
This is somehow connected to bug 73957, although it's not exactly the same problem. The "External Plug-in Libraries" project has both bundles on the (flat) classpath: - implementation class RWGuiComponent is declared in bundle "rw.ui" (JAR from the target platform) - interface GuiComponent is declared in the workspace project "gui", which is also in the "org.eclipse.pde.core.externalJavaSearch" classpath container
I found that the "gui" project gets dropped here for focus = "gui" project; javaProject = "External Plug-in Libraries" project:
IndexSelector.canSeeFocus(IJavaElement, JavaProject, char[][][]) line: 124 IndexSelector.canSeeFocus(IJavaElement[], JavaProject, char[][][]) line: 86 IndexSelector.initializeIndexLocations() line: 220 IndexSelector.getIndexLocations() line: 276 JavaSearchParticipant.selectIndexURLs(SearchPattern, IJavaSearchScope) line: 121 SubTypeSearchJob(PatternSearchJob).getIndexes(IProgressMonitor) line: 84 SubTypeSearchJob.getIndexes(IProgressMonitor) line: 33 SubTypeSearchJob(PatternSearchJob).execute(IProgressMonitor) line: 59 IndexManager(JobManager).performConcurrentJob(IJob, int, IProgressMonitor) line: 277 IndexBasedHierarchyBuilder.searchAllPossibleSubTypes(IType, IJavaSearchScope, Map, IPathRequestor, int, IProgressMonitor) line: 523 IndexBasedHierarchyBuilder.determinePossibleSubTypes(HashSet, IProgressMonitor) line: 406 IndexBasedHierarchyBuilder.build(boolean) line: 120 TypeHierarchy.compute() line: 300
With knowledge of IndexSelector#canSeeFocus(..) line 114, I disabled auto-build and then cleaned all projects without starting a rebuild.
=> Now, the type hierarchy on "GuiComponent" is complete. Search for references doesn't work, but that's because reference search only works with attached source (bug 127442; it works if I copy RWGuiComponent.java into the JAR).
It looks like the fix for bug 102279/bug 313668 needs to take into account that a JAR on the classpath can also refer to a project in the same classpath. The current code that uses the build state only seems to consider references from source files to a class in a JAR.
Unfortunately, I don't see an easy fix.

Created attachment 224799 incomplete patch
I found an incomplete/untested patch for this in my workspace. Attaching here just in case I or someone else resumes work on this.

We're using your patch now for several months (Eclipse 4.2) and it works great - thank you very much! Is there any chance that this patch will make it into an official Eclipse version?
(In reply to Markus Keller from comment #5) > Created attachment 224799 [details] > incomplete patch > > I found an incomplete/untested patch for this in my workspace. Attaching > here just in case I or someone else resumes work on this.
Jay, please have someone review/complete the patch.
Manoj, please take it to completion. Please note that, as Markus himself has acknowledged, the patch is untested and I see some TODO flags as well.

Moving to 4.4 M6
Confirmed that the Type Hierarchy scenario described in the bug is fixed by the patch. Couldn't get a test case created. Moving to M6 due to lack of time.

Applied the partial patch by commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=56ca67916705c5ee00cbe5e33bc882242243e4fd
Moving out of M6 for the rest of the stuff (test case + remaining part)
moving out due to time pressure :(

(In reply to Manoj Palat from comment #12) > Moving to 4.5
Since the Type Hierarchy problem is resolved by Markus' patch the other issue remaining is about references which is tracked by bug 127442 - refer comment 4. Hence planning to close this bug. Markus: any comments?
